excerpt: Romantic medieval castle restored after fire with ornately decorated rooms & an armoury museum.
detail_description: The Alcázar de Segovia is a romantic medieval castle that has been restored after a fire. It features ornately decorated rooms and houses an armoury museum. The fortress, dating back to the 12th century with construction believed to have started in the 11th century, was completed in 1587 during the Renaissance period by Spanish architect Francisco de Mora.
name: Alcázar de Segovia
address: Pl. Reina Victoria Eugenia, s/n, 40003 Segovia, Spain

excerpt: This 15th-century building features a facade with 617 granite points & a Renaissance courtyard.
detail_description: Casa De Los Picos is a 15th-century building in Segovia, known for its facade adorned with 617 granite points and a Renaissance courtyard. The city's Jewish Quarter, once home to a thriving Hebrew community until their expulsion in the 15th century, offers picturesque narrow streets and historic buildings.
name: Casa De Los Picos

detail_description: Plaza Mayor, located in Segovia, serves as the central town square and a popular gathering spot. The bustling area is filled with charming shops, inviting cafes, and delightful tapas restaurants. One side of the plaza is graced by the impressive Segovia Cathedral, adding to the picturesque ambiance of this vibrant hub.
name: Plaza Mayor

excerpt: Historic 13th-century Catholic church with a unique 12-sided exterior built by the Knights Templar.
detail_description: Iglesia de la Vera Cruz is a 13th-century Catholic church with a distinctive 12-sided exterior, originally built by the Knights Templar. Situated on the outskirts of town, this isolated Romanesque church offers a captivating visit for those intrigued by medieval history and legends. The unique architectural style, adorned with the Knights emblem carved into the stone, evokes images of crusades and chivalric orders.
name: Iglesia de la Vera Cruz

excerpt: Towering Roman aqueduct & grand landmark monument, constructed with 2 tiers and 167 arches.
detail_description: Segovia Aqueduct is a towering Roman monument with 167 arches, making it a grand landmark. The old quarter of Segovia and the Aqueduct are part of a World Heritage site, offering visitors a glimpse into the town's rich history. Exploring the city walls reveals other notable attractions such as Casa de los Picos, Alhondiga, Torreon de Lozoya, and the church of San Martin.
name: Segovia Aqueduct

excerpt: 1100s church noted for its monumental Romanesque architecture & views of Segovia's old town.
detail_description: Iglesia de San Millán is a remarkable 12th-century church in Segovia, known for its monumental Romanesque architecture. Situated beyond the fortified historic center, it offers stunning views of the old town. The church features a Mozarabic tower, atrium, and apses, showcasing Segovian 12th-century art. Its architecture reflects both Romanesque style and Islamic influence with Caliphate-inspired vaulting and ornamentation.
name: Iglesia de San Millán

excerpt: Segovia is a historic city northwest of Madrid, in central Spain's Castile and León region. Its centuries of settlement have resulted in a rich architectural legacy, including medieval walls, Romanesque churches, a former royal palace and a Gothic cathedral. Its iconic ancient Roman aqueduct has more than 160 arches, most in the original mortarless granite, and stands above Plaza Azoguejo in the heart of the city.
detail_description: Segovia, a historic city in central Spain's Castile and León region, boasts a rich architectural legacy with medieval walls, Romanesque churches, a former royal palace, and a Gothic cathedral. The iconic ancient Roman aqueduct with over 160 arches stands in the heart of the city. The area is known for its wide variety of pork products and traditional dishes like pigeon stuffed with wild mushrooms and partridges cooked Segovian style.
name: Segovia

excerpt: The quiet, medieval Jewish Quarter is home to the city’s former main synagogue, seized in 1410 and converted into the Convent of Corpus Christi. On Calle Judería Vieja, the Centro Didáctico de la Judería is a museum on local Jewish life in a 15th-century home. Forested El Pinarillo park is the site of a Jewish cemetery, with graves carved into limestone. A few bars dot the area, along with a Sephardic eatery.
detail_description: The Jewish Quarter, a serene and historic area, was once the center of the city's Jewish community until their expulsion in the 15th century. The former main synagogue has been transformed into the Convent of Corpus Christi, while Calle Judería Vieja is home to the Centro Didáctico de la Judería, a museum showcasing local Jewish life. El Pinarillo park houses a Jewish cemetery with limestone-carved graves.
name: Jewish Quarter

excerpt: 17th century palace and gardens based on Versailles design decked out in antiques and paintings.
detail_description: The Royal Palace of La Granja of San Ildefonso is a 17th-century baroque palace located in the town of San Ildefonso, just 12 kilometers east of Segovia. The palace and its stunning formal French gardens were modeled after the Palace of Versailles by Philip V. Construction began in 1721, resulting in a highly impressive complex with majestic rooms adorned with antiques, paintings, and tapestries.
name: Royal Palace of La Granja of San Ildefonso
address: Pl. de España, S/N, 40100 Real Sitio de San Ildefonso, Segovia, Spain

excerpt: Striking late-Gothic cathedral lined with 1300s stained glass, plus art-filled chapels & a museum.
detail_description: The Catedral de Segovia is a stunning late-Gothic cathedral in Spain, featuring 1300s stained glass and art-filled chapels. It was built in the 16th century to replace an earlier cathedral destroyed during a revolt. Designed by Juan Gil de Hontanon and executed by his son Rodrigo, the cathedral showcases a transition from Gothic to Renaissance style. The interior is illuminated by 16th-century Flemish windows and features a wooden neoclassical choir.
name: Catedral de Segovia
address: C. Marqués del Arco, 1, 40001 Segovia, Spain

excerpt: Petite grassy area known for its postcard-perfect views of the medieval Alcázar castle.
detail_description: Mirador de la Pradera de San Marcos is a free lookout point offering stunning views of the medieval Alcázar castle in Segovia. The hike up to this grassy area may be tiring, but the panoramic vistas of the castle's spires and its rocky foundation make it worthwhile. Located below the castle, this viewpoint provides an excellent vantage point for capturing photos of the castle, often likened to the front of a ship.
name: Mirador de la Pradera de San Marcos
address: C. de San Marcos, 19, 40003 Segovia, Spain

excerpt: Medieval church founded in the 12th century & added to over hundreds of years in different styles.
detail_description: Iglesia de San Martín is a medieval church located in Segovia, founded in the 12th century and expanded over time with various architectural styles. The church showcases Castilian Romanesque architecture and features notable elements such as the Gothic Capilla de Herrera, which houses the tombs of the Herrera family, and the Capilla Mayor with a remarkable recumbent figure of Christ by Gregorio Fernandez.
name: Iglesia de San Martín

excerpt: 15th-century Hieronymite monastery complex with noted artworks & views of Segovia from the tower.
detail_description: The Monastery of Santa María del Parral, located just outside the walls of Segovia, is a remarkable Roman Catholic monastery complex with a rich history dating back to the 15th century. This impressive site showcases late Gothic and Mudejar architectural styles and is home to a stunning church with an impressive facade. Notable artworks and the tombs of King Henry IV of Castile and Queen Maria of Aragon can be found within its walls.
name: Monastery of Santa María del Parral

detail_description: When visiting Segovia, don't miss the enchanting Plaza de Medina del Campo, a historical site that showcases a fusion of Christian and Jewish religion. The area also features the Romanesque Church of St. Martin and the main places of Jewish Segovia, including its old main Synagogue. As you continue your tour, take in the majestic Cathedral of Segovia at Plaza Mayor with its exterior guarded by gargoyles and prophetic angels.
name: Plaza de Medina del Campo
address: Pl. Medina del Campo, 40001 Segovia, Spain

detail_description: Nestled in the southern section of Segovia's historic city walls, Puerta de San Andrés, also known as Arco del Socorro, stands as a magnificent testament to medieval architecture. This impressive gate not only connects various parts of the fortifications but also served as a vital entry point to the Jewish Quarter. With its towering structure adorned with steep arches and intricate cornices, it’s truly an architectural marvel that captures the essence of Segovia's rich history.
name: Puerta de San Andrés
address: C. Martínez Campos, s/n, 40003 Segovia, Spain

detail_description: Located near Casa de los Picos, Mirador de la Canaleja offers a different perspective of Segovia. While it doesn't provide views of the main attractions, it overlooks the city and offers a picturesque backdrop of mountains. Just a short walk from the aqueduct, this viewpoint is easily accessible and worth a quick visit for some memorable photos.
name: Mirador de la Canaleja
address: Bajada de la Canaleja, 2, 4, 40001 Segovia, Spain

detail_description: Nestled in the heart of Segovia, the Iglesia de San Esteban is a stunning medieval church that dates back to the 12th century. This architectural gem is particularly famous for its impressive Romanesque bell tower, which stands at an astonishing 56 meters—making it the tallest of its kind in the Iberian Peninsula.
name: Iglesia de San Esteban

excerpt: Former royal mint dating to the 1500s, now a museum dedicated to coins & industrial heritage.
detail_description: Nestled beside the Eresma River and near the iconic Alcázar, the Museo Real Casa de Moneda de Segovia is a fascinating glimpse into Spain's industrial heritage. Originally established as a royal mint in the 16th century under Philip II, this historic site showcases the evolution of coin production from its inception in 1586 until it ceased operations in 1869. While not located within Segovia’s Old City, it's easily accessible and offers stunning views of the surrounding landscape.
name: Museo Real Casa de Moneda de Segovia
address: C. la Moneda, s/n, 40003 Segovia, Spain

excerpt: Contemporary art museum in a 15th-century royal palace with rotating exhibits, lectures & concerts.
detail_description: If you're a fan of abstract and contemporary art, the Museum of Contemporary Art Esteban Vicente is a must-visit. Located in a converted 15th-century palace that was once owned by Henry IV, this museum features the extraordinary works of Spanish painter Esteban Vicente from the 20th century. The gallery's modern exhibition spaces are entirely dedicated to Vicente's extensive collection, showcasing 153 works in various mediums.
name: Museum of Contemporary Art Esteban Vicente
address: Pl. Bellas Artes, S/N, 40001 Segovia, Spain

detail_description: Iglesia de San Clemente is a 12th-century Romanesque church located in Segovia, Spain. It features a blend of Romanesque and Gothic styles and is often overlooked by visitors despite its excellent state of preservation. The church's architecture, including blind arched apse and Mudejar bell, showcases the typical Romanesque style of Segovia.
name: Iglesia de San Clemente

detail_description: The Monasterio de San Antonio el Real in Segovia, Spain is a captivating historical site that was originally a royal palace built by King Henry IV in the 15th century before being converted into a monastery for the Franciscan order. The monastery showcases stunning Gothic and Mudejar architectural styles, with towering spires and intricate detailing on its facade.
name: Monasterio de San Antonio el Real, Segovia
address: C. San Antonio el Real, 6, 40004 Segovia, Spain

excerpt: Enduring museum dedicated to local archaeology, ethnology & fine arts, housed in a former fortress.
detail_description: Casa del Sol - Museo de Segovia is a captivating museum situated in the picturesque city of Segovia, Spain. Housed in a former fortress, this enduring museum offers an extensive look into the local archaeology, ethnology, and fine arts. The exhibits within showcase a wide array of artifacts dating from prehistoric times to the modern era.
name: Casa del Sol - Museo de Segovia

detail_description: Fundación Torreón de Lozoya, located in Segovia, is a must-visit for art enthusiasts. This historical site was once a defensive tower but has now been transformed into an exhibition center hosting temporary exhibitions and collections of both new and old artworks. Visitors can admire pieces ranging from Dali to Dante while also enjoying stunning views of Segovia by climbing the tower. The foundation also hosts cultural activities, making it a vibrant hub within the city walls.
name: Fundación Torreón de Lozoya

detail_description: When visiting Segovia, a city rich in history and architectural wonders, the Plaza del Azoguejo is a must-see destination. This former main square, located beneath the iconic aqueduct, showcases the diverse influences of past inhabitants, including Christian, Jewish, and Muslim cultures.
name: Plaza del Azoguejo

excerpt: Rustic, 1800s half-timbered house beneath a Roman aqueduct, known for roasted suckling pig.
detail_description: Mesón de Cándido is a legendary restaurant located in a rustic 1800s half-timbered house beneath a Roman aqueduct in Segovia. It is renowned for its roasted suckling pig, which is the most famous local dish. The city also offers traditional museums such as the Antonio Machado House-Museum and surprising new spaces like La Carcel, a former prison turned into an exhibition and cultural center.
name: Restaurante Mesón de Cándido

excerpt: Jewish museum & education center in a historic house that was built in medieval times.
detail_description: The Centro Didáctico de la Judería de Segovia is a museum and education center located in a historic house dating back to medieval times. Situated in the Jewish Quarter of Segovia, it offers insights into the rich history of the Jewish community that inhabited this area from the 12th century until their expulsion in 1492. The museum provides an informative experience about Jewish medieval culture and the historical significance of the community in Segovia.
name: Centro Didáctico de la Judería de Segovia
address: C. la Judería Vieja, 12, 40001 Segovia, Spain

detail_description: Mirador del Alcázar y los dos Valles is a must-visit spot in Segovia, Spain. It offers stunning views of the majestic Alcázar de Segovia, as well as the surrounding churches and convents. The short walk/hike to reach this viewpoint is worth it for the breathtaking scenery. Accessible by car, visitors can park at a turnout on C and take a brief stroll to reach the mirador.
name: Mirador del Alcázar y los dos Valles
address: C. Cta. de los Hoyos, 76, 40003 Segovia, Spain

excerpt: Museum dedicated to the poet Antonio Machado in the home he lived in from 1919–1932.
detail_description: The Casa-Museo de Antonio Machado is a museum dedicated to the poet Antonio Machado, who lived in this home from 1919 to 1932. The museum contains his furnishings and personal effects, and is very ornate. Although I'm not particularly interested in literature, the museum was very nice.
name: Casa-Museo de Antonio Machado

excerpt: Cozy nook offering small plates, international dishes & local beers in a warmly decorated space.
detail_description: Pasapán is a charming and inviting restaurant located in Segovia, offering a mix of traditional and innovative market cuisine. The cozy space is beautifully decorated, creating a warm and welcoming atmosphere for diners. The menu features an array of small plates, international dishes, and local beers, providing a delightful fusion of flavors. From cod brandade with romesco sauce to grilled picanha and cochinita pibil tacos, the restaurant offers an enticing selection of must-try dishes.
name: Restaurante Pasapán

detail_description: C. Juan Bravo is a contemporary dining destination that is not currently featured in the MICHELIN Guide. However, as the guide continues to expand its coverage, there may be a selection of restaurants in this area in the near future.
name: C. Juan Bravo

detail_description: The Murallas de Segovia, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, are the remnants of medieval city walls with origins dating back to the Roman period around 200 AD. The existing walls were constructed in the 11th century and stretch for approximately 3.4 kilometers with an average height of 9.5 meters and a thickness of 2.5 meters. Over time, houses became attached to these walls, adding to their historical charm.
name: Murallas de Segovia

detail_description: C. Alcázar is a must-see in Segovia, offering a journey through time with its historical and architectural wonders. The castle, perched on a hill, boasts turreted towers and hidden passageways that seem straight out of a novel. Climbing the 152 steps of the spiral staircase in the Tower of Juan II rewards visitors with unique views reminiscent of a boat cutting through waves.
name: C. Alcázar

excerpt: Ávila, capital of the Spanish province of the same name, is a city in the rolling hill country northwest of Madrid. It’s best known for its intact medieval city walls, with 80-plus crenelated, semicircular towers and 9 gates, including the arched El Alcázar, on the eastern side. Long sections atop the walls are walkable. At night, the lighted walls are a distinctive sight.
detail_description: Ávila, the capital of its namesake province in Spain, is a picturesque city located in the rolling hills northwest of Madrid. The city is renowned for its well-preserved medieval walls, featuring over 80 crenelated towers and 9 gates, including the impressive El Alcázar. Visitors can walk along long sections of the walls and admire their illuminated beauty at night.
name: Ávila‎

excerpt: Built in the 15th century, this Gothic-Mudejar architecture features religious art & mosaics.
detail_description: Castillo de Coca is a magnificent medieval fortress located in the province of Segovia, Spain. Constructed in the 15th century, it showcases a blend of Gothic and Mudejar architecture, incorporating Christian and Islamic design elements. The castle features impressive brick walls, intricate decorative details, and formidable towers. It is renowned for being one of the best-preserved castles in Spain.
name: Castillo de Coca
address: Avenida Banda de Música, 40480 Coca, Segovia, Spain

excerpt: Italian-style 1700s palace with ornate interiors, surrounded by a vast forest of oak & ash trees.
detail_description: The Riofrío Royal Palace is a beautiful palace with ornate interiors, surrounded by a vast forest of oak and ash trees. The palace visit includes spectacular chambers and a hunting museum. The building is wonderful and the grounds are lovely as well. Very economical as well.
name: Riofrío Royal Palace
address: Bosque de Riofrío, 40420 Navas de Riofrío, Segovia, Spain

detail_description: Nestled in the heart of Segovia's Plaza Mayor, the Iglesia de San Miguel is a stunning Gothic-style church that dates back to the 16th century. This architectural gem was built after the original church dedicated to Saint Michael was demolished. It stands as a testament to both faith and history, having served as a vital community hub where significant events unfolded, including the crowning of Queen Isabel.
name: Iglesia de San Miguel
address: C. de la Infanta Isabel, 1, 40001 Segovia, Spain

detail_description: When exploring the enchanting city of Segovia, one cannot overlook the breathtaking Mirador del Valle del Clamores. Nestled just before the entrance to the iconic Alcazar, this viewpoint is a gem that offers stunning panoramas of both the historic city walls and the majestic cathedral towering over old town buildings.
name: Mirador del Valle del Clamores
address: Rda. de Don Juan II, 24T, 40003 Segovia, Spain

detail_description: The Muralla de Segovia is a historic landmark in the city of Segovia, in the north-eastern region of Spain. The walls date back to the 11th century and are one of the most impressive and well-preserved remnants of medieval fortifications in Europe. The walls feature characteristic crenellations, blind arches, towers, and entrance gates with horseshoe arches.
name: Paseo Don Juan II Defensive Wall
address: Rda. de Don Juan II, 20, 40003 Segovia, Spain

detail_description: Years ago, I made a visit to the Monumento a Juan Bravo after seeing it featured in an episode of my favorite anime, Attack on Titans. To my delight, the monument lived up to its portrayal in the show. It was truly impressive and I highly suggest taking some photographs of this remarkable place. The statue itself is particularly striking and definitely worth checking out.
name: Monumento a Juan Bravo
address: Pl. Medina del Campo, s/n, 40001 Segovia, Spain

detail_description: Nestled near the iconic Roman Aqueduct in Segovia, the Santos Justo and Pastor Church is a stunning example of 12th-century Romanesque architecture. This hidden gem boasts an impressive apse adorned with remarkable wall paintings that date back to the late 12th century, captivating visitors with their historical significance. The church features the tallest tower in Segovia, offering a striking silhouette against the skyline. Although it has undergone restoration, it beautifully preserves its original charm.
name: The Santos Justo and Pastor Church

detail_description: Colección de Títeres Francisco Peralta is a unique puppet museum located near the Alcazar, close to the wall and Puerta de Santiago in Segovia. The museum showcases an impressive collection of puppets and mechanisms created by Francisco Peralta. Visitors can explore the history and functioning of puppets while enjoying the symbolic entrance fee, which includes an audio guide for an immersive experience. Additionally, there are underground dungeons to visit, adding to the overall experience.
name: Colección de Títeres Francisco Peralta
address: C. la Prta de Santiago, 36, 40003 Segovia, Spain

excerpt: Ornate sanctuary of the patron saint of Segovia in an open meadow with a serene atmosphere.
detail_description: Santuario de Nuestra Señora de la Fuencisla is an ornate sanctuary located in a serene meadow, dedicated to the patron saint of Segovia, Virgen de Fuencisla. The sanctuary features an impressive altarpiece and a small museum for visitors to explore. It offers a peaceful escape from the crowds and provides picturesque views of the surrounding area.
name: Santuario de Nuestra Señora de la Fuencisla
address: P.º Segundo Rincón, s/n, 40003 Segovia, Spain

detail_description: Palacio Episcopal, also known as the Bishop's Palace, is a historical building located just a short walk from Plaza Mayor in Segovia. It was once the residence of local bishops and now houses an impressive collection of artworks, sculptures, and religious artifacts. Visitors can gain access to the palace with their entrance ticket to the cathedral. The interior showcases how the higher clergy lived in Segovia and features numerous religious works of art.
name: Palacio Episcopal

detail_description: The Paseo del Salón, situated along Calle Cervantes and Calle Juan Bravo in Segovia's Jewish Quarter, offers a serene atmosphere and captivating scenery. As you stroll towards the Puerta de la Luna arch, adorned with intricate decorations depicting geographical and botanical motifs, you'll be enthralled by the facades of the buildings. Along this route, you'll also encounter the charming San Martin church showcasing remarkable Romanesque art and the Casa de los Picos house.
name: Paseo del Salón
address: P.º Salón Isabel II, 40002 Segovia, Spain

detail_description: The Postigo de San Juan de los Caballeros is a medieval church located in the upper town of Segovia, Spain. Built in the 11th century, it was once the burial place of the leading families of Segovia. The church features Romanesque architecture and is today a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
name: Postigo de San Juan de los Caballeros

detail_description: The Statue of the Devil, also known as the Angel Caido (Fallen Angel) statue, is a unique depiction of the Prince of Darkness before his transformation. It's a popular spot for taking photos, with many visitors recommending it as a must-see attraction. The statue's intricate details and enigmatic qualities make it an intriguing piece of art to explore.
name: Statue of the Devil
address: Pl. del Conde de Cheste, 6, 40001 Segovia, Spain

detail_description: The Torre de Juan II del Alcázar de Segovia offers a breathtaking panoramic view of the city and its surroundings. Climbing 152 steps to reach the top, visitors are rewarded with stunning vistas that include the cathedral and snow-capped mountains in the distance. This medieval Castilian military fortification showcases excellent preservation and provides an insight into the transition to firearms during that era. The tower's interior features a combination of military utility and elegant design, particularly on its lower floors.
name: Torre de Juan II del Alcázar de Segovia
address: Pl. Reina Victoria Eugenia, S/N, 40003 Segovia, Spain

detail_description: Loba Capitolina, also known as the Capitoline Wolf, is a significant monument located in Segovia, Spain. This majestic bronze replica depicts the iconic scene of Romulus and Remus suckling on a wolf, symbolizing the founding myth of Rome. The statue was gifted to Segovia by Rome in 1974 to commemorate the 2000th anniversary of the Roman aqueduct.
name: Loba Capitolina

detail_description: The Torre de la Catedral in Segovia is one of the city's two tallest towers, alongside the Alcazar. Visitors can enjoy a guided tour of the tower and explore its history, including the functioning bells that have been in place for over 600 years. The ticket price also includes access to the Cathedral, a stunning example of late Gothic architecture, as well as the cloister and Episcopal Palace.
name: Torre de la Catedral
address: Old City, C. Marqués del Arco, 1, 40001 Segovia, Spain
